title: Erdős Problem #385: Composites and Least Prime Divisors
description: Is F(n) = max{m + p(m) : m < n composite} greater than n for all large n, where p(m) is the least prime divisor?

overview.historicalContext: This problem was posed by Erdős, Eggleton, and Selfridge. It connects to deep questions about prime distribution, sieve theory, and Siegel zeros. Terry Tao discussed it in a 2024 blog post.
overview.problemStatement: Let F(n) = max{m + p(m) : m < n, m composite}, where p(m) is the least prime divisor of m. Question 1: Is F(n) > n for all large n? Question 2: Does F(n) - n → ∞?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines composite numbers, least prime divisor, and the function F(n). It states both questions as conjectures, provides upper/lower bounds, and connects to related problems.
keyInsights: F(n) ≤ n + √n (trivial upper bound since p(m) ≤ √m for composite m)
Equivalent to Problem #430 for large n (Sarosh Adenwalla)
Connected to prime gaps and the parity problem in sieve theory

sections.title: Basic Definitions
sections.description: Composite numbers and least prime divisor

sections.title: The Function F(n)
sections.description: Maximum of m + p(m) over composites m < n

sections.title: Known Bounds
sections.description: Upper bound n + √n and conjectured lower bound

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #385 asks two questions about F(n), the maximum of m + p(m) over composites. Both remain open, though plausible prime conjectures would imply F(n) > n for large n.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would reveal structure in how composites with small prime factors are distributed. The connection to Siegel zeros makes this particularly deep.
openQuestions: Are there infinitely many n with F(n) ≤ n?
What is the growth rate of F(n) - n?
How does this relate to prime gap conjectures?
